titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Red Hot Organization Archive
1989-2004
MSS 191
titlestmt.subtitle: MSS 191
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by YZ Chin, 2009.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-07-02T11:55-0400

did.abstract: The Red Hot Organization is an international organization dedicated to fighting AIDS through pop culture. First founded as King Cole, Inc. by Leigh Blake and John Carlin in 1989, Red Hot Organization has since produced fourteen albums, related television programs and media events incorporating the talents of performers, visual artists, producers and directors to raise funds and awareness for HIV and AIDS. The collection contains the production files of the organization's projects, including administrative records and financial files, and merchandise such as CDs, videos, and t-shirts. The collection also contains raw and finished film, video, and audio media, which is currently unprocessed and not available for research use.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Red Hot Organization is an international organization dedicated to fighting AIDS through pop culture. First founded as King Cole, Inc. by Leigh Blake and John Carlin in 1989, Red Hot Organization has since produced fourteen albums, related television programs and media events incorporating the talents of performers, visual artists, producers and directors to raise funds and awareness for HIV and AIDS.

To date, Red Hot's efforts have donated nearly 7 million dollars for AIDS relief around the world. Besides funding AIDS research and education, Red Hot awarded grants in cooperation with existing AIDS organizations, such as the National Minority AIDS Council. Revenues from the sale of albums and videos in foreign countries remained within each respective country to help support local AIDS prevention and relief.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Red Hot Organization Archive contains the production files of the organization's projects, including administrative records and financial files, and merchandise such as CDs, videos, and t-shirts. The collection also contains raw and finished film, video, and audio media, which is currently unprocessed and not available for research use. CDs and other media found in Merchandise series may be accessible upon request.
Numerous oversize items found at the end of each of the series include t-shirts, posters, and other oversize promotional material housed in boxes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Red Hot Organization Collection is generally organized into series by Red Hot Organization projects undertaken between 1990 and 2005. The series are arranged chronologically according to each project's release date.
Materials within series are arranged alphabetically, with all efforts made to preserve the original titles and classifications of the collection.
The collection is organized into 24 series:

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The Red Hot Organization Archive; MSS 191; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Red Hot Organization Archive was donated to the Fales Library by Red Hot's founder, John Carlin, in 2006.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All researchers wishing to use this collection must receive the approval of the Fales director or archivist. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections.

Film, video and audio media (other than merchandise products) are currently unprocessed and not available for research use. CDs and other media found in "Merchandise" subseries may be accessible upon request.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Blue was released in 1990 and was the first in the Red Hot series. Red Hot + Blue featured contemporary pop performers reinterpreting the songs of Cole Porter. An accompanying television special featured videos for all but two songs.
In 2006 Red Hot + Blue was re-issued on a special two-disc set including the original CD remastered, and a DVD of the home video.
(Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Dance was released in 1992 by Columbia Records, featuring three exclusive tracks from George Michael. Other major dance artists donated tracks, remixed by D.J.s and producers from around the world. An accompanying home video was released by Sony Music Video Enterprises. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)
An anomaly exists in Series II: Red Hot + Dance. An additional series, designated as Subseries L, pertains to the legal dispute between George Michael and Sony Music.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Contains sticky note listing artists and song titles, and a letter from The Burt Bacharach Music Group.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: No Alternative was released in 1993 by Arista Records. An MTV special and home video featuring live performances, music videos, and information about AIDS was released by PolyGram Video in 1993. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Country was released in 1994 by Mercury Nashville, featuring classic country and rock songs performed by old and new country artists. The album received two Grammy nominations. An accompanying home video was released by PolyGram Video. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

Series VI: Stolen Moments: Red Hot + Cool

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Stolen Moments: Red Hot + Cool was released by GRP Records in 1994, featuring collaborations between jazz performers and hip hop artists. A documentary film focusing on the impact of AIDS on communities of color was broadcast on PBS in tandem with the album release, and released on home video by PolyGram Video. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Bothered was initially released in 1995 as "Red Hot + Bothered Volume I Number 1" and "Red Hot + Bothered Volume I Number 1," two 10” EP's with limited edition fanzines by indie writers and artists. A full-length CD was later released in the same year, containing extra tracks not available on the vinyl EP's. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

Series VIII: The Beat Experience / Offbeat: A Red Hot Soundtrip

odd.head: General
odd.p: This series encompasses both "The Beat Experience" CD-ROM/Video and "Offbeat: A Red Hot Soundtrip" enhanced audio CD.

Released by WAX TRAX / TVT in 1996, "Offbeat: A Red Hot Soundtrip" was an offshoot of The Beat Experience, a project exploring the legacy of the Beat generation produced by The Red Hot Organization in association with the Whitney Museum of American Art. "The Beat Experience" CD-ROM combines text, jazz, underground films and visual art to anthologize the period, while "The Beat Experience" video is an hour TV show that presents the era in a contemporary edit of archive filmclips, sound bites, music and abstract imagery.
(Reference: Offbeat: A Red Hot Happening flier; http://www.redhot.org)

scopecontent.p: America Is Dying Slowly was released in 1996 by Eastwest Records America. It features hip hop producers and rappers who had not previously worked together. (Reference: http://redhot.org)

scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Rio was released by VERVE ANTILLES in 1996 and is a tribute to the Bossa Nova sound, with a focus on compositions by Antonio Carlos Jobim. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

Series XI: Silencio=Muerte: Red Hot + Latin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Silencio = Muerte: Red Hot + Latin was originally released in 1997 on Jellybean Benitez’ H.O.L.A Recordings. In celebration of the album's ten-year anniversary, it was re-released in 2006 as Red Hot + Latin Redux by Nacional Records, featuring new bonus tracks and remastered tracks from the original release. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

Series XII: Every Nation (from "Diana, Princess of Wales - Tribute")

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Every Nation is a song composed by R. Kelly and included in the tribute album "Diana, Princess of Wales - Tribute." (Sony, 1997) Various artists contributed to the track, and they were collectively credited as "Red Hot R+B All Stars." (Reference: Amazon.com)

did.unittitle: Diana, Princess of Wales - Tribute; Sony
Selections from Diana, Princess of Wales - Tribute; Sony
Series XIII: Onda Sonora: Red Hot + Lisbon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Onda Sonora: Red Hot + Lisbon was released in 1998 by Bar/None in North America, Movieplay Portuguesa in Europe, and Trama in Brasil. The album features 40 artists from 11 countries singing in 7 languages, and was created in conjunction with the 1998 World Expo in Lisbon Portugal. A donation of $100,000 was made in Red Hot's name by Imperio Seguradora. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Rhapsody, a George Gershwin tribute album, was released by Verve/Antilles in 1998. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

Series XV: Optic Nerve: David Wojnarowicz on CD-ROM

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Optic Nerve: David Wojnarowicz on CD-ROM was released by Red Hot Organization in 1999. Optic Nerve was produced by Red Hot Organization and Funny Garbage in conjunction with the New Museum of Contemporary Art's exhibit, Fever: The Art of David Wojnarowicz. The CD-ROM encompasses music, writing, film, painting and performance by Wojnarowicz.

Optic Nerve was originally available from the New Museum bookstore in New York City. $4 per unit from the sale of each disc was donated to the Hetrick Martin Institute, which Wojnarowicz supported during his lifetime.
(Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

did.unittitle: "Postcards from America, X-Rays from Hell: the life and times of David Wojnarowicz"
"Angel with a Gun," article on David Wojnarowicz by John Carlin
Art in America article on Wojnarowicz
Press release for readings from "Close to the Knives"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Indigo, a Duke Ellington tribute, was released by Red Hot Organization in 2000, after an agreement for the album to be released by a record company fell through.
All About the Blues is a compilation produced for Liz Claiborne, featuring women artists singing the blues.
(Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

did.unittitle: "All About the Blues," a Red Hot compilation for Liz Claiborne of legendary ladies singing the blues
All About the Blues / Liz Claiborne

Series XVII: Artists Against AIDS Worldwide - "What's Goin' On"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: What's Going On was released in 2001 by Sony in collaboration with Artists Against AIDS Worldwide (AAAW), featuring remakes of Marvin Gaye's "What's Going On." AAAW was founded by Leigh Blake, co-founder of Red Hot Organization. (Reference: Amazon.com)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Red Hot + Riot, a Fela Kuti tribute, was released by MCA Records in 2002. The album features Femi Kuti, Fela Kuti's son. A companion film, Red Hot + Riot: Encounters with AIDS in Africa, was released by Red Hot Organization. (Reference: http://www.redhot.org)

did.unittitle: DVD / The New Museum of Contemporary Art
